head.title: Oil-Tank Cleanups Caught In the Web of Bureaucracy

hedline.hl1: Oil-Tank Cleanups Caught In the Web of Bureaucracy

abstract.p: Environmental Protection Agency project manager Stephen Cipot letter on July 9 article describes how New York Department of Environmental Conservation can speed up cleanup of leaking residential oil tanks on Long Island (S)

block.p: If it takes the Department of Environmental Conservation 13 months to satisfy the liability concerns of just one innocent landowner to win access to investigate a single leaking underground storage tank, one wonders in what new millennium the D.E.C. is planning to survey the other 500,000 tanks on the Island.
While environmental problems are time consuming and costly to address, it is the torpid and piecemeal approach that allows a bad problem to become worse.

If it takes the Department of Environmental Conservation 13 months to satisfy the liability concerns of just one innocent landowner to win access to investigate a single leaking underground storage tank, one wonders in what new millennium the D.E.C. is planning to survey the other 500,000 tanks on the Island.
While environmental problems are time consuming and costly to address, it is the torpid and piecemeal approach that allows a bad problem to become worse.

The department's heavy-handed approach of pinning the delay on befuddled citizens is the semiquaver of inefficient government. No amount of petulant whining by harried bureaucrats will resolve these foibles.

Since access can be a nagging issue at all sites, standard operating procedure should be for the D.E.C. to have its contractors add property owners' names to their general liability insurance policies, rather than drag out the process by craftily holding this in reserve as a negotiating tool.
It costs nothing to do so and, in the long run, is more efficient than the current legal wrangling.
STEPHEN CIPOT Project manager Environmental Protection Agency Garden City
